modules.description: This module constructs well-known security identifiers using predefined authority values and sub-authorities. It provides functions for creating SIDs associated with specific system entities like null, world, local, creator, and NT authorities. These functions are used to represent standard security principals in Windows environments, such as system-wide groups or mandatory labels.

This module handles binary serialization and deserialization of Security Identifiers (SIDs), providing precise conversion to and from byte buffers and I/O channels with configurable endianness for subauthority fields. It operates directly on `Sid.t` values, decoding from and encoding to raw bytes, with explicit support for reading and writing SIDs in binary protocols or file formats. Concrete use cases include parsing SIDs from network packets or Windows binary structures and emitting them in low-level system interactions where exact byte layout matters.

This module provides predefined security identifiers (SIDs) and construction functions for well-known Windows system entities, built-in accounts, and domain groups. It operates on `Sid.t` values and utilizes 32-bit unsigned integers to represent domain or machine identifiers when generating SIDs for dynamic contexts. These capabilities are primarily used in access control, authentication, and security context management within Windows environments.

Converts between string representations and `Sid.t` values. Parses strings into SIDs using `decode` and converts SIDs to strings using `encode`. Useful when handling Windows security identifiers in text format, such as reading from configuration files or displaying in logs.

This module converts SIDs to and from their string representations with permissive input validation. It operates directly on the `Sid.t` type, parsing strings into structured SIDs and formatting SIDs into standardized string form. It is used when importing or exporting Windows-style security identifiers, such as during inter-process communication or log file processing.

This module implements Security Identifiers (SIDs) used in Windows systems, offering operations to construct, compare, and manipulate SIDs in both binary and string formats. It provides functions to create SIDs from identifier authorities and subauthorities, convert between string and binary representations with configurable endianness, and compare SID components directly. Concrete use cases include parsing SIDs from Windows logs, serializing SIDs for network transmission, and working with well-known system SIDs for access control decisions.
